text: hi guys I'm Laura Vitale today I'm going
to show you something that's been in my
family for years and years and years and
if you follow me for a long time then
you have seen me eat these before they
are my Nona's delicious preserved
eggplant I wasn't planning on sharing
this recipe with you but I mentioned it
that I mentioned on social media what
not that I was planning on making a few
jars for Christmas and everyone asks if
I could show you how I do them now what
you need to keep in mind is I usually do
many many many many batches of this like
I usually make a really huge batch and
many many jars today I'm only making a
few jars for my dad and I for Christmas
and I'm going to show you step by step
on how I make them it's really important
that you follow through and just really
watch each step because it's going to be
next to impossible for me to write the
recipe in detail on my website because
it's really hard to kind of measure
everything everything is by eye and
weight and all that stuff so what I have
here the most important thing of course
on is my eggplant now you'll see these
are quite small compared to what your
normal eggplant would be like in your
grocery store normally you know here in
the US the eggplants are really really
big and then we're kind of soft those
are not the kind of eggplant you need to
use for these because there's so much
sort of softness so many seeds those are
going to fall apart what you need are
small tight and somewhat firm eggplants
often known as Italian eggplant these
are what you're looking for it it should
be about the size of your hand and not
much wider so these are perfect and when
I find them I grab a bunch of them so
that I can do this process now the first
thing I'm going to do is you need to cut
and peel your eggplant and this is how I
do them this is my Nonna's method I have
never ever ever ever ever changed it I
never will change it this is the only
way I've ever known how to do it so
that's just the way I do it and then I
just take a vegetable peeler and I just
peel the skins off and the pet vegetable
peeler works better than a knife because
you don't end up losing so much of the
actual eggplant sometimes it'll snow
bag but that's okay just take your time
and peel each one I've got all my
eggplant nicely peeled and I have some
that I've already obviously most of it
everybody prepped and this is how I like
to do it this is how my Nonna does it
you you cut like circles you cut like
rings like that and they all have to be
about the same thickness between a
quarter and a half an inch thick you
don't want to go too thick but you don't
want to go too thin because if you go
too thin what's going to happen is you
know during the process of where they're
sitting in the oil and they're
preserving it one nob they'll get really
really soft and then it'll just be like
a paste instead of the eggplant which
nobody wants that and then you go ahead
and you slice them into little
matchsticks now like I said it's the
only thing you need to keep in mind it's
important is that they're all about the
same thickness but if some are bigger
than others you know depending on which
side of the eggplant you cut that's
perfectly fine and I have them in a
colander I have two calendars one little
one and a bigger one because we need to
press these with some salt it's really
really important that you do that for
several hours because it just gets rid
of any bitterness you add those to a
colander got just a few more slices to
go and you can see what you know it's
important that you use smaller eggplants
because they don't have all those soft
scenes because that's what's going to
fall apart and it's not going to be good
it's not going to be what you want it's
not traditional you just don't you know
that's just not yet one that you use
which is why I don't make these often
because I can't always find the right

a really big colander now what I have
here usually I would do this at the sink
but because I want to show you I'm going
to do this here I've got some kosher
salt
you take your closure soft and it's
really important that you just toss your

about a half a cup of kosher salt and

plant on top like so
and you weigh these down and then you

these look great they were pressed and

what I have here is a large stockpot a

third of the way filled with water you
want to do equal parts water and
distilled white vinegar now this is when
this recipe will vary from family to

might not now on the other hand would
never in a million years consider making

either I prefer them with vinegar so
much more than just oil because just oil

there's not it just kind of flat to put
the vinegar is what makes these so so so
so fantastic so I'm going to have to

really you just want equal parts water

vinegar balsamic no other vinegar will
do has to be white then I've got some

oil olive oil isn't good here because
olive oil has a really strong flavor and
also when you go to refrigerate these
once you've opened them olive oil will
solidify in the fridge and that's not
what you want and my Nonna always uses
sunflower oil so that's what I've always
used
all I'm going to do is wait for that to
come to a boil I have two baking sheets

then we'll proceed my vinegar water
makes sure it's up to a boil do not add
any salt to this because remember the
eggplant is still coated in salt now all
we do is you need to kind of work
quickly you need to add your eggplant to
the boiling water I'm gonna do this in
batches because I don't want to
overcrowd my pan and each batch only
needs one minute now I know it doesn't
sound like it's a lot of time but trust
me when I tell you it literally needs to
be in this boiling water for one minute
when I did this once I used really big
eggplant I let this boil for more than a
minute I think was around two or three
minutes it ruined everything
I ended up in tears because I was so
frustrated and I made this I made sure
to never make that mistake again so let
that boil for just a minute and you can
see I'm constantly keeping them moving
keeping an eye on the clock and then
what you do as soon as it hits that one
minute mark you add them onto your paper
towel lined baking sheet just to absorb
any extra water work quickly and then
it's important that you place these on a
single layer well as much as you can in
a single layer on your baking sheet with
your paper towels because what you don't
want is for that to be like a big pile
of them and then they'll steam and then
some of them will overcook and then it's
just a mess so you need to work quickly
kind of spreading these out you feel
like you've got too many here and then
enough there we can move them around oh
these are hot okay
then add some strong vinegar my Nana
always does is you take a clean kitchen

these cool with your kitchen towel
pressing on it like so to absorb any
excess water once your eggplant has
cooled completely you add it all to a
large bowl and then you add sliced
garden
like hot pepper flakes and some oil at
this point you just add enough oil to
get everything coated and then what I
have here are some clean jars these are
all mismatched they're just leftover jam
jars olive jars pickles what-have-you
this is how my nono does it she uses
mix-match jars that you just have laying

and that's what I'm going to use to
because they work really well and there
are all different sizes which is great

mix everything together you want to make
sure that that garlic is really
distributed well throughout the eggplant
and then you just place them into your
jars and then you just make sure to add
enough oil to cover the eggplant
completely but you see what I'm doing
I'm starting with a little bit and then
moving to the next one because you just
need to be able to give the oil just a
few seconds to seep all the way through
those nooks and crannies of the eggplant
and that's pretty much it you just want
to make sure that you are using a clear
oil like I said nothing too heavy you
certainly don't want to use an extra

so that is what I use as well and all
you do is just wipe off each rim you

have to seal them really really well so
just put the tops on like that and then
I'll do it with the the cow just like my

this is sort of her method that I've
done that she's done for years and years
and then I've just copied and then you
just take two towels and you tighten

these just go in the pantry you don't

go right in your pantry they're not
edible just yet they need to have a
couple of weeks minimum I always like to
eat them
at the two-week mark they seem to be
